CUTTIE.</br>Willy well met, now whiles thy flockes do feed</br>So dangerlesse, and free from any feare;</br>Lay by thy Hooke, and take thy pleasant Reed,</br>And with thy melody reblesse mine eare;</br>Which (upon Lammas last) and on this plaine,</br>Thou plaidst so sweetly to thy skipping Traine.

WILLY.</br>I Cutty, then I plaid unto my sheepe</br>Notes apt for them, but farre unfit for thee:</br>How should my layes (alas) true measure keepe</br>With thy choyce eares, or make thee melodie:</br>For in thy straine thou do'st so farre exceede,</br>Thou canst not rellish such my homely Reede.

CUTTIE.</br>Thy nicenesse shewes thy cunning, nothing more.</br>Yet since thou seem'st so lowly in thy thought;</br>(Who in thy pastorall veine, and learned lore</br>Art so much prais'd; so farre and neere art sought.)</br>Lend me thine eares, and thou shalt heare me sing</br>In praise of Shepheards, and of thee their King.

My loved WILLY, if there be a Man</br>That never heard of a browne colour'd Swan;</br>Whose tender Pinions scarcely fledg'd in show</br>Could make his way with whitest Swans in Poe;</br>Or if there be among the Spawne of earth,</br>That thinkes so vilely of a shepheard's birth,</br>That though he tune his Reed in meanest key,</br>Yet in his braine holds not heaven, earth, and sea:</br>Then let him know, thou art that yong browne Swan,</br>That through the winding streames of Albion</br>Taking thy course dost seeme to make thy pace</br>With flockes full-plum'd equall in love and grace;</br>And thou art he (that though thy humble straines</br>Do move delight to those that love the plaines:)</br>Yet to thy selfe (as to thy sort) is given</br>A JACOBS staffe, to take the height of Heaven;</br>And with a naturall Cosmography,</br>To comprehend the earths rotunditie:</br>Besides the working plummet of thy braine,</br>Can sound the deepes and secrets of the maine:</br>For if the Shepheard a true figure be</br>Of Contemplation (as the learn'd agree)</br>Which in his seeming rest, doth (restlesse) move</br>About the center, and to Heav'n above;</br>And in his thought is onely bounded there,</br>See's Nature's chaine fastned to JOVES high Chaire,</br>Then thou (that art of PAN the sweetest Swaine</br>And farre transcending all his lowly traine)</br>In thy discoursive thought, do'st range as farre</br>Nor canst thou erre; led by thine owne faire starre.</br>Thought hath no prison and the minde is free</br>Under the greatest King and tyrannie.</br>Though low thou seem'st thy Genius mounts the Hill</br>Where heavenly Nectar doth from Jove distill;</br>Where Bayes still grows (by thunder not struck down)</br>The Victors-Garland and the Poets-Crowne,</br>And underneath the Horse-foote-fount doth flow,</br>Which gives Wit verdure, and makes learning grow.</br>To this faire Hill (from stormes and tempests free.)</br>Thou oft repair'st for Truthes discovery;</br>A prospect upon all times wandring mazes,</br>Displaying vanity; disclosing graces,</br>Nay in some cliffe it leades the eye beyond</br>The times horizon, stripping sea and land.</br>And farther (not obscurely) doth devine</br>All future times:  Heere do the Muses shine,</br>Heere dignity with safety do combine,</br>Pleasure with merite make a lovely twine.</br>Vitam vitatem they shall ever leade</br>That mount this hill and Learning's path do treade:</br>Beere admiration without enui's wonne,</br>All in the light, but in the heate sit none.</br>And to this Mount thou dost translate thine Essence</br>Although the plaines containe thy corporal presence,</br>Where though poore peoples misery thou shewe</br>That under griping Lords they undergoe,</br>And what content they (that doe lowest lye)</br>Receive from Good-men, that doe sit on hye.</br>And in each witty Ditty (that surpasses)</br>Dost (for thy love) make strife 'mongst Country-lasses</br>Yet in thy humble straine, Fame makes thee rise</br>And strikes thy mounting forehead 'gainst the skies</br>Renowned friend; what Trophe may I raise</br>To memorize thy name; would I could praise</br>In any meane) thy worth; strike envy dumbe,</br>But I dye heere; thou liv'st in time to come;</br>States have their Period statues lost with rust:</br>Soules to Elizium, Nature yields to dust,</br>All monuments of Armes and Power decay,</br>But that which lives to an Eternall day,</br>Letters preserve; Nay Gods, with mortall men</br>Do simpathize by vertue of the penne.</br>And so shalt thou:  sweete Willy then proceede</br>And in eternall merite fame thy Reede.</br>PAN to thy fleeced numbers give increase</br>And Pales to thy love-thoughts give true peace</br>Let faire Feronia (Goddesse of the woods)</br>Preserve thy yong Plants multiply thy buds.</br>And whiles thy Rams do Tup, thy Ewes do twyn</br>Do thou in peacefull shade (from men's rude dyn)</br>Adde Pinyons to thy Fame:  whose active wit</br>With Hermes winged cap doth suite most fit.</br>
